problem.markdown:
A loyal warrior has three arrows left in the quiver. The enemy is far away and the chance of victory seems slim. The warrior estimates the chance of landing a successful shot is p = 0.3.
>> a. What is the probability that the first arrow will land? (numerical input, 10% tolerance) << =0.3+-0.03 [Explanation] The probability of shot being successful is 0.3. Therefore, the probability of the first shot being successful is 0.3. [Explanation]
>> b. What is the probability that the first will not but the second arrow will land? (numerical input, 10% tolerance) << =0.21+-0.021 [Explanation] \( P(X_g = 2) = (1-0.3)^{(2-1)}*0.3 = 0.21 \) [Explanation]
>> c. What is the probability that the first two will not but the third arrow will land? (numerical input, 10% tolerance) << =0.147+-0.015 [Explanation] \( P(X_g = 3) = (1-0.3)^{(3-1)}*0.3 = 0.147 \) [Explanation]
>> d. The strategy of the warrior’s army is that a warrior should fight if the probability of a successful shot is greater than or equal to .5; if not, the warrior should run away. Should the warrior fight or run away? << (x) Fight ( ) Run away [Explanation] \( P(victory) = P(X_g = 1) + P(X_g = 2) + P(X_g = 3) = 0.657 \) [Explanation]
